awd_titl_txt: FRG: Collaborative Research: Computational Methods for Complex Fluids: Adaptivity, Fluid-Structure Interaction, and Applications in Biology
awd_abstract_narration:
Many biological systems involve flexible structures immersed in viscoelastic fluids (e.g., sperm in the reproductive tract, bacteria in the gut and lung,ciliary transport of mucus in the lung). In some cases, such as cilia-driven transport in the lung, these structures operate in a multi-fluid environment. Despite decades of work explicit challenges remain with developing suitable computational tools for the modeling of the complex fluid-structure interactions. The goal of this project is to develop and analyze accurate computational methods for these simulations, and to establish high-performance open-source implementations of these tools to be used by other researchers.  The new computational tools together with experimental measurements will be used to generate new insight into the mechanical behavior of mucus. Mucus provides a protective barrier for every human organ, and many diseases and disorders are associated with mucus pathology (e.g., in the lung (COPD, cystic fibrosis, asthma), stomach (ulcers),reproductive tract (infertility)). Moreover, tools developed as part of these projects have applications beyond mucus: to the food industry, for personal care products, as well as pharmaceutical applications, including drugs and drug delivery systems. The project will also provide broad interdisciplinary training for graduate students and postdoctoral researchers in the mathematical sciences.

The specific research objectives of this project are 1) to develop and analyze efficient higher-order accurate numerical methods for fluid-structure interaction and fluid-fluid interaction problems involving complex fluids, 2) to validate these methods by comparison to experimental data of project collaborators, and 3) to develop mathematical models of industrial and biological systems, including microbead rheology, ciliar synchronization and transport, and phase separation of suspensions. Previous research on numerical methods for viscoelastic fluids has been driven by engineering applications, while biological applications pose new challenges: large deformations of active soft structures and complex rheology. Despite past efforts to understand the dynamics of active structures in complex fluids, a significant bottleneck persists: the lack of accurate, efficient, adaptive numerical methods and software for viscoelasstic fluid-structure interaction and fluid-fluid interfaces. The research team aims to build, validate, and apply this technology, guided by applications and experimental data from biology and engineering.

por.por_cntn:
This research developed new computational methods and  mathematical models and used  mathematical analysis to understand problems involving complex fluids including biological locomotion, particle dynamics in electric fields, and the fundamental physics of viscoelastic flow. Below is a brief summary of some of the major outcomes from these projects.

The Immersed Boundary (IB) method has been extremely popular for biological problems involving fluid-structure interaction with large deformations common in biology, but the cost of this robustness is the low-order accuracy of the conventional IB method.  We developed the IB Smooth Extension method (IBSE) which can achieve higher-order accuracy while retaining many of the desirable properties of IB methods. We extended the IBSE method to viscoelastic fluids and presented numerical tests on the classical (and extremely challenging) viscoelastic flow around a cylinder problem. We showed that the IBSE method was able to obtain solutions with accuracy that is comparable to high-order body fitted meshes using a structured Cartesian grid.

The IB methods have been extended to problems including motion of rigid bodies undergoing prescribed deformations, but methods for these problems involve specialized solvers that are computationally prohibitive for large scale applications. We recently showed that IB methods for rigid objects are related to integral equations, and we used this connection to develop the IB Double Layer (IBDL). Our new IBDL method inherits the good conditioning of second-kind integral equations and can thus solve IB problems extremely rapidly. The IBDL method is much more robust than integral formulations. Further, this method can be applied to nonlinear problems such as Navier-Stokes and large classes of non-Newtonian fluids without modification, provided the nonlinearity is discretized explicitly in time.

We performed numerical simulations of biflagellated cells swimming in viscoelastic fluids using swimming gaits that were fit from experimental data. Our simulations provided the first mechanistic explanation of how fluid elasticity affects locomotion in this type of swimming. This work led to two follow-up studies on viscoelastic flows around flagella.  Large localized stresses around the flagellum tip had been repeatedly observed in computational models, but their physical origin and significance on locomotion were not understood.  We analyzed the flows around bending and translating thin filaments in viscoelastic flows. We showed that filaments moving tangential to their axis produce higher elastic tip stresses compared to normally moving rods. This orientation/stress relationship is reversed from classical viscous fluid theory, and it has the potential to reshape our understanding of locomotion in viscoelastic fluids.

 

The elastic stresses that build up in polymeric fluids can produce instabilities and complex turbulent flows even at small scales where flows of classical Newtonian fluids are always laminar.  We used a dimension reduction technique to understand and classify the observed transitions of the flows in a 3D four-roll mill flow (driven by four rollers to create extreme stretching between them). This technique is  commonly applied to turbulent flow, but to the best of our knowledge, it  was not applied to viscoelastic flows in the Stokes regime.
 

We examined the emergence, regulation, and optimality of coordinated movements in different types of swimming organisms. We developed a model of nematode swimming that involved the coupled dynamics of the body, the surrounding fluid, and a minimal neural circuit. We used the model to understand how this simple organism senses the environment and adapts its gait in response. We used computational modeling to explore the optimal paddling rhythm of long-tailed crustaceans such as krill, lobsters, and crayfish. We showed that this natural back-to-front metachronal paddling rhythm is optimal at both large scales where vortex dynamics are significant and at small length scales where inertia is negligible.

 

Experiments observing the motion of colloids suspended in large amplitude oscillatory electric fields displayed unexpected behavior, including coalescence, disaggregation, and apparent "levitation" above electrodes. We published a series of papers involving both careful numerical and analytical calculations of this problem to explain for the first time the physics behind these mysterious observations. Our work revealed that there is an induced DC (non-oscillatory) component to the total electric field when the mobilities of the anion and cation differ, as expected in real systems. Our work resolves several discrepancies between previous theoretical predictions and experimental observations that are important for applications.  One early application of nonlinear electroosmotic flows is liquid pumping via asymmetric electrodes subject to AC electric potentials (ACEO). Previous theory failed to predict the observed reversal in the direction of fluid flow at high frequencies and that the flow direction depends on the identity of the electrolyte present. Our theory predicts these effects and explains the physical mechanism behind them.

 

This project partially supported the work of two postdoctoral scholars, five graduate students, and four undergraduates. All trainees received broad interdisciplinary training including working with data and interfacing directly with experimental collaborators to learn the essential skill of communicating ideas across disciplines.
